I've been interested in getting some barefoot shoes for a while after dealing with some toe issues from overly narrow shoes. Many of the shoes I've seen were too expensive or looked like clown shoes. When I saw these were cheap and looked decent, I decided to pull the trigger and I am thoroughly impressed. The fit feels great, plenty of room in the toes, they look nice, the sole is pliable. If they last for a reasonable timeframe I would definitely purchase again. My only downside I've noticed is the insole has a bit more cushion than I would like in a barefoot shoe.
The eyelets broke almost immediately whilst lacing up.  Cheap material.

You know how some compact cars are low and make you feel like your butt is only two or three inches off the ground? Well, these shoes are like that in a way. They make you feel the only thing between you and the pavement is a very thin material. If I were a young man I might buy this shoe again. I am not so, I need a substantial shoe to support. These shoes are not support shoes. Young feet do not need support shoes as much as old feet. There is another aspect or uniqueness to the shoe. It "kurplops".  Think of a clown shoe. When the clown takes a step the heel touches, then the rest of the shoe plops down. Sometimes you can hear the "kurploping". When you go into a dinner with friends, no one wants to be "kurploping"! So, the shoe forces you to try to walk differently so there is no "kurploping". This effort detracts from a comfortable evening. Instead of enjoying your friends you are wondering if you are "kurploping". No. I would not buy the shoe again.

While I can't recall how long my last pair lasted, my most recent pair last me 3.5 months of everyday use (roughly 6,000 -10,000 steps a day) before I recently discoveredthat I wore through the sole.  For 30 bucks they weren't the worst thing to ever go on my feet, I did like them, but they sure don't last long. Go with a name brand.

These are cool looking shoes. I have been looking for a casual all day shoe that aren't Altras or over 100 bucks with the zero drop. However, the second I put them on I realized I could never wear them. I take one step and the shoe comes partly off my heel, kinda like a flip flop. However, if I'm working I need to move well and quickly, this would get very annoying and tiresome fast. Length wise they fit perfect so I know this is not a size issue, however I do have fairly small feet.

评论概述: Perfect for Casual Comfort and Versatile Wear
评论详情: I recently tried out the relxfeet Men's Barefoot Shoes, and they have quickly become my go-to for both workouts and casual wear around town. While I wouldn't recommend them for trail running, they excel as minimalist cross-trainers. As someone working in law enforcement, I wear these on my casual days, and they provide the comfort I need while still allowing me to perform my duties in the field if necessary. The wide toe box and zero drop sole add to the overall comfort and natural feel. Highly recommended for those looking for a versatile and comfortable pair of sneakers.

评论概述: I just walked 4 miles with these then wrote this review.
评论详情: Its main feature is the price- you get a shoe that is similar to Adidas NMD or Ultraboost with its knit construction, without a foam sole for a cheaper cost. That’s where the good stops.  The images and video make it seem like this is a real “zero drop” shoe but I measure 38mm height. The sole is also very rigid and stiff, despite the memory foam-like upper layer. My fake Vans have a thinner and more flexible sole than this. The sizing is also off, feeling looser which made for a painful walk with the heel part of the shoe sliding off. Feels like you’re walking in sandals with these. Very disappointed because I expected a lightweight and extremely flexible shoe. This feel like regular slip-on Vans for those who are familiar with them, for the stiffness.

I’ve bought a couple of name brands when it comes to barefoot shoes. Vivos being my favorite. Therefore I was skeptical of these. But I actually really enjoy these. The sole is a bit stiffer than a vivo shoe. However, I personally find it more comfortable for my type of usage. The insole feels good, you can pull it out for a more barefoot feel. Toe box is perfect. And it has padding on the posterior part of your ankle which feels comfortable.
I like the padding and the style, but the sizes definitely run small.

Worth the money imo and for a wide toe shoe the style isn't bad.

My husband has wide feet. It's very hard to find good looking, light and comfortable shoes. He got two pairs on this. He wears them with shorts and jeans.

Get a pair, if you're thinking about trying barefoot shoes. I've been wearing these every day for about 2 weeks now. Doing walks of at least 8,000 steps. (Although, I needed a few days to build up to that level of foot strength in these shoes. 2,000 steps one day, 3,000 steps the next, etc.)  The way I walk has changed distinctively since wearing them. More space for my toes to spread, I feel more stable throughout the day, even my posture is better. Some ankle pain that I've had for a few months is now gone.  The shoes are true to your size. Get your size or even a half size up. They're like protective gloves for your feet.

The sole is very flexible and versatile. I thought the sole would be thicker on the inside to match the outside. Overall it is flat on the inside and has toe pockets toward the front of the shoe. My feet are a size 13 and I ordered a 12.5. The options only allow half size up or down.  The 12.5 fits perfect so much so that it would make a huge difference if you cut your toe nails or not. I would recommend not to order a half size up it might be to big. You wont have to worry about the heel slipping off easily like other low cut shoes. The heel is snug and holds on to the heel.
They are not that comfortable as I thought they were going to be.
